Funds for Chester Community Charter School children will begin being released around June 5th. ALL children are eligible for this benefit. Each child will receive approximately $370.50.

Because there are so many schools receiving this benefit, please allow the Department of Human Services a few weeks to process and distribute these funds.

Any additional questions can be directed to the Department of Human Services, the CCCS website, or the school’s general voicemail.

Thank you and stay healthy!

CCCS alum Churon T. Lanier-Martin was featured by Gettysburg College for his achievements while studying abroad! We're proud of you, Churon!

Check out his inspiring profile below:
shared_text:
GETTYSBURG.EDU
Churon T. Lanier-Martin ’20: Seeking the betterment of himself and the world

Gettysburg College
May 13 at 11:21 AM ·

Coming from a childhood of poverty in Pennsylvania, Churon T. Lanier-Martin ’20 wanted to use his college experience to understand other cultural perspectives. Upon studying abroad in Indonesia, he found that differences are forged by social constructions. “The only way to change anything is to take responsibility [for those constructions, and] assess how you could help alleviate social woes,” he said.

Crozer Health
November 4, 2019 at 11:31 AM ·

Seventh and eighth-grade students at Chester Community Charter School participated in a career day on Wednesday, October 30. The day was organized by Joe Rafferty, Vice President of Outpatient and Ambulatory Care Services Business Development, and Dr. David Clark, CEO of Chester Community Charter School, to expose students to various career opportunities and get them thinking about the connection between school and work.

Gwen Smith, Executive Director of Patient Experience of Care, Nursing Home Initiatives, Community Outreach, and Volunteer Programs; Rick Pescatore, D.O., FAAEM, Director of Clinical Research, EMS Medical Director, Department of Emergency Medicine; Lieutenant Paramedic Nicholas Scull and Field Training Officer Paramedic Ramona Bucolo from Crozer EMS South, were on hand to speak about their careers in healthcare.

Special thanks to Dr. Clark and his team at Chester Community Charter School, for inviting Crozer-Keystone to participate in this important educational event.

post_text: West B had their First Annual Career Day on March 8, 2019. The scholars had a very exciting day and engaged in informational sessions touching on a wide variety of careers. West C hosted a parent engagement event honoring and celebrating the VIM (Very Important Male) or Dad’s in our scholars lives. The event completely surpassed our expectations. What a turn out! We witnessed as 100 men showed up to hear about our school message expressing our needs and how they play an integral role in the growth and development of our scholars.
Conversations were positive, uplifting and promising, for a bright partnership. We feel the best is yet to come and we broke down many barriers.
What was supposed to be a 45 minute pow-wow with the dads to encourage them to get involved turned into a very engaging, informational meet & greet. We even had some dads sign up to volunteer at the school to help out with our scholars.

FREE food, fun for kids all summer long!
Free summer meals are available to kids and teens across the country. Many summer meals sites offer fun learning and recreational activities so kids and teens can eat a healthy meal while staying active and being with friends.

Meals are free to children and teens ages 18 and younger and follow federal nutrition guidelines. At open sites, parents do not need to apply to the program or show proof of income to get a free summer meal for their kids. Simply bring your child to a summer meals site in your community.

To locate open meal sites, text “summer meals” to 97779, visit https://www.fns.usda.gov/summerfoodrocks or e-mail SFSPCommunication@ag.state.nj.us.

Congratulations go out to West B 5th graders, Ayres Robinson and Janya Shields, who have been selected among 1,600 entries nationwide to have their STEM artwork included in Crayola's education publications. Ayres and Janya submitted their work as part of Crayola’s 2017-2018 Art Energizes STEAM Art Exhibition. Each submission provided a look into the mind of the student artist. We were truly inspired by the ways students connected art with science, technology, engineering, and math.
While the artwork selected for the U.S. Department of Education permanent collection has reached maximum capacity, company officials wrote that they were so inspired by the duo’s submissions that we'd like to provide an opportunity for this art to be included in Crayola education resources. Way to go students!
